comment.author: 88025703@N00
comment._content:
Sad Bishop and George have it right. The equipment was way to fragile and cumbersome, and so the photog's grounds (owned or rented) were a studio, supposedly reflecting reality or some ideal of it. 
BTW - the body on that fellow is amazing, different from most in these photos; quite possibly a real fisherman who didn't need a rowing machine.

comment.author: 34988929@N06
comment._content: It's great to see that composition was as important then as it seem to be now.

comment.author: 64838194@N02
comment._content: Why would the woman be knitting while standing up? And look at the ground--are those huge, egg-shaped pebbles or oyster shells? They're very odd...

comment.author: 31580040@N04
comment._content:
@MyLilliesMyLo

The floor is made of flint nodules, they also built houses, churches and walls from them in the east of England.  She looks more like a child doing the knitting, but whatever her age, knitting was done as an accompaniment to other activities.  You wouldn't waste the time spent walking to school by just walking, you'd knit as well.

comment.author: 64838194@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/31580040@N04] Fascinating! So I guess we would call that "multi-tasking" (a truly impossible thing, mentally). I always thought that flint nodules were angular, which lead early humans to think, "Hey! A possible tool!", but I guess I was wrong. And it's nice to know that England isn't entirely made out of chalk...as some think--not ME--but some! P.S. The reason I though the floor was made of shells is that a tavern near us served steamed clams (a Northeast US "delicacy"), and just chucked the shells into the parking lot. They looked EXACTLY like these!

comment.author: 31580040@N04
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/64838194@N02] The natural shape of flint nodules is roundish (and white) but it breaks easily. When it's used for building it's knapped into squares so it's easier to fit together. There's a flint built church in this photo www.flickr.com/photos/calotype46/5963010071/

comment.author: 64838194@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/31580040@N04]  Thanks for that link--it gives a very different view of the English countryside and buildings. When I think of flint, it's always in terms of tools at Olduvai Gorge or drilling for oil in the American midwest!

comment.author: 65918449@N05
comment._content: The man looks so modern, the girl not so much.
